Prompt: An employee in England is currently on maternity leave under the Employment Rights Act 1996. During her leave, her employer announces a redundancy process due to company restructuring. Additionally, there are health and safety concerns at the workplace that might affect her return. Considering the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999 (as amended), the Equality Act 2010, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, and relevant case law, what protections does she have during redundancy, and how should the employer proceed?
Actual Answer: Under the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999, specifically Regulation 10, if an employee on maternity leave is at risk of redundancy, she must be offered any suitable alternative vacancy available before it is offered to other employees, giving her priority for redeployment opportunities. The Equality Act 2010, particularly Section 18, prohibits discrimination because of pregnancy or maternity, requiring employers to ensure that redundancy selection criteria do not disadvantage employees on maternity leave to avoid unlawful discrimination claims. Regarding health and safety, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, Regulation 16, mandates employers to perform a specific risk assessment for new or expectant mothers, and if risks are identified and cannot be avoided, the employer must adjust her working conditions or hours, offer suitable alternative work on no less favorable terms, or if no alternative is available, suspend her on full pay. Relevant case law, such as Sefton Borough Council v Wainwright [2014] EWCA Civ 953, confirms the obligation to offer suitable alternative employment to employees on maternity leave before others. Therefore, the employer must conduct a fair and non-discriminatory redundancy process, prioritize the employee for any suitable alternative positions, and address health and safety concerns by performing risk assessments and taking necessary actions to protect the employee.
Response:
The employee in question has several protections under various regulations when facing redundancy while on maternity leave:

1. **Unfair Dismissal Protection**: Under the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999 (as amended), she is protected from being dismissed due to pregnancy or maternity leave, meaning her employer cannot discriminatorily select her for redundancy based on her pregnancy.

2. **Sex Discrimination Protection**: The Equality Act 2010 prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex, including pregnancy and maternity status. If redundancy decisions are based on gender or pregnancy, this could constitute illegal discrimination.

3. **Health and Safety Protections**: The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 require employers to ensure a safe working environment. If returning would pose health risks, she may have grounds to refuse until safety is ensured.

4. **ACAS Code of Practice**: The redundancy process must follow this code, which includes fair consultation, offering severance packages, and ensuring non-discriminatory criteria in selection.

**Employer's Responsibilities:**
- Follow due process, including the ACAS Code, to ensure fairness.
- Assess health and safety concerns regarding her return.
- Avoid any discriminatory practices related to her pregnancy or leave status.

In conclusion, the employee has significant protections against unfair dismissal and discrimination, with the employer required to adhere to legal standards during redundancy procedures.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations amend the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/3312), the Paternity and Adoption Leave Regulations 2002 (S.I. 2002/2788) and the Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014 (S.I. 2014/3050). They also amend the Paternity and Adoption Leave (Adoption from Overseas) Regulations 2003 (S.I. 2003/921) and the Shared Parental Leave and Paternity and Adoption Leave (Adoptions from Overseas) Regulations 2014 (S.I. 2014/3092) to ensure equivalent provision for those adopting children from overseas.
The amendments extend existing requirements that apply to employers when redundancy situations arise where an employee is on maternity, adoption or shared parental leave, so that those requirements can also apply during pregnancy and for a period of time after that leave has ended. For those taking shared parental leave who have not taken maternity or adoption leave, there is a six-week threshold of continuous leave that needs to be met for the requirements to apply for a period of time after shared parental leave has ended. Where the six-week threshold is not met, the requirements apply during shared parental leave.
A full impact assessment has not been produced for this instrument as no, or no significant, impact on the private, voluntary or public sector is foreseen. A full impact assessment has been prepared in relation to the Protection from Redundancy (Pregnancy and Family Leave) Act 2023 and to which this instrument gives effect, and a copy is available at https://bills.parliament.uk/bills/3191/publications.

12.—(1) An employee is entitled under section 47C(1) of the 1996 Act not to be subjected to any detriment by any act, or any deliberate failure to act, by an employer because—
(a)
the employee took, sought to take, or made use of the benefits of, parental bereavement leave, or
(b)
the employer believed that the employee was likely to take parental bereavement leave.
(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(a), an employee makes use of the benefits of parental bereavement leave if, during a period of parental bereavement leave, the employee benefits from any of the terms and conditions of employment preserved by regulation 9 during that period.
(3) Paragraph (1) does not apply where the detriment in question amounts to a dismissal within the meaning of Part 10 of the 1996 Act.
(1)

Prompt: A tenant in England reports a malfunctioning carbon monoxide alarm installed under the Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Alarm (Amendment) Regulations 2022. Despite notifying the landlord, the alarm has not been repaired or replaced after three weeks. The tenant is concerned about safety and compliance. Under the Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Alarm Regulations 2015 (as amended), what are the landlord's legal obligations, and what actions can the tenant take?
Actual Answer: Under Regulation 6 of the Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Alarm (England) Regulations 2015, when a landlord is served with a remedial notice for breaching one or more duties outlined in Regulation 4(1) (such as failing to install or maintain smoke or carbon monoxide alarms), the landlord must take the specified remedial actions within the timeframe set out in Regulation 5(2)(d), typically 28 days from the notice's issuance. This regulation imposes a clear duty on the landlord to address the breach promptly and ensures tenant safety through enforcement mechanisms. However, Regulation 6(2) provides that a landlord will not be considered in breach of this obligation if they can demonstrate that they have taken all reasonable steps, short of initiating legal proceedings, to comply with the duty. Reasonable steps may include hiring contractors, arranging access to the property, or documenting efforts to resolve tenant-related barriers to compliance. Proper evidence of these steps is crucial to establish the landlord’s diligence. This provision ensures that while landlords are held accountable, genuine efforts to comply are recognized, even if the issue remains unresolved due to circumstances beyond their control.
Response:
The landlord's responsibilities under the Smoke and Carbon Monoxide Alarm (Amendment) Regulations 2022 in England are as follows:

1. **Legal Obligations**: Landlords must ensure that all required smoke and carbon monoxide alarms are installed and functioning correctly. If notified of a malfunctioning alarm, they must promptly repair or replace it.

2. **Timeframes**: There may be specific requirements regarding the response time, possibly within a certain number of days, to avoid penalties for non-compliance with housing safety standards.

3. **Consequences of Non-Compliance**: Failure to address the issue can result in fines and other legal actions as landlords are obligated to maintain safe living conditions for tenants.

4. **Tenant Rights**: Tenants have the right to demand that the landlord take action. If the landlord fails, tenants may repair the issue themselves or seek assistance from local authorities.

5. **Evidence Requirements**: Landlords must provide proof of repairs or replacements, such as receipts or maintenance logs, upon tenant request.

6. **Legal Recourse**: Tenants can take legal action if their safety is compromised, including seeking injunctions or other remedies through relevant courts.

In summary, landlords are legally bound to address faulty alarms promptly, and tenants have the right to enforce this, ensuring their safety and compliance with regulations.

3.—(1) Subject to paragraph (2), a landlord in respect of a private tenancy must ensure that each dwelling-house has—
(a)
a smoke alarm installed in—
(i)
the room, including an open plan living area, which is most frequently used by the occupants for general daytime living purposes; and
(ii)
every circulation space on each storey;
(b)
a heat alarm installed in every kitchen; and
(c)
a carbon monoxide alarm installed in any room or circulation space of the dwelling-house which contains a fixed combustion appliance or a flue.
(2) Where the proximity of an open fireplace would make a smoke alarm impracticable, a heat alarm may be fitted.
(3) A landlord may dispense with the paragraph (1)(a)(i) requirement relating to a smoke alarm in circumstances where the room includes an open plan living area, provided the heat alarm in the kitchen is installed in a position where it is not more than 7.5 metres from any point in the room.
(4) The landlord must ensure that each smoke, heat or carbon monoxide alarm is—
(a)
in proper working order at the beginning of every new tenancy;
(b)
replaced when notified the alarm is faulty;
(c)
replaced before the manufacturer’s specified date of expiry.

Prompt: An apprentice in England has turned 19 and has completed the first year of their apprenticeship. However, they are still being paid the apprenticeship wage, which is lower than the National Minimum Wage for their age. Under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 (as amended) and the National Minimum Wage Regulations 2015, what are the apprentice's rights regarding wages, and what steps can they take if their employer is not compliant?
Actual Answer: An apprentice in England has turned 19 and has completed the first year of their apprenticeship. However, they are still being paid the apprenticeship wage, which is lower than the National Minimum Wage for their age. Under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 (as amended) and the National Minimum Wage Regulations 2015, what are the apprentice's rights regarding wages, and what steps can they take if their employer is not compliant?
Response:
**Apprentice's Wage Rights and Remedies in England**

**Understanding Entitlements:**
- **Age and Apprenticeship:** Once an apprentice turns 17 and has completed their first year, they are entitled to receive the National Minimum Wage (NMW) instead of the apprenticeship pay rate. This entitlement is enforceable under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998.
  
**Current NMW Rates (as of recent updates):**
- **Lower Earnings Limit:** £4.15 per hour for workers aged 17 and older, effective from April 2023.

**Employer's Obligations:**
- Employers are legally required to pay apprentices aged 17 or older at least the NMW if they have completed their first year of apprenticeship, regardless of the apprenticeship scheme duration. This ensures that such workers are not paid below the minimum wage.

**Steps for the Apprentice:**

1. **Understand and Assert Rights:**
   - The apprentice should be aware that upon turning 19 and completing their first year, they are entitled to the NMW. If still paid the apprenticeship wage, this constitutes a breach of their rights.

2. **Contact HMRC:**
   - The apprentice can report the issue to the HMRC helpline dedicated to minimum wage queries. This can be done via phone or through an online form available on the GOV.UK website.

3. **Seek Advice from Organizations:**
   - For guidance and support, the apprentice can contact organizations like Citizens Advice, TUC, or ACAS (Advisory Conciliation Service). These bodies can assist in understanding legal entitlements and may help with formal complaints.

4. **Escalate Through Official Channels:**
   - If the employer does not comply after initial contacts, the apprentice can escalate the issue to the Department for Business and Trade (DBT) or the Gangmasters and Labourers Act 2014 Unit, as these bodies handle enforcement of minimum wage laws.

5. **Potential Legal Action:**
   - Persistent non-compliance by the employer may lead to legal action, including fines for the employer through HMRC or DBT investigations.

**Conclusion:**
The apprentice has a enforceable right to receive the National Minimum Wage once they meet specific criteria. They should take proactive steps such as contacting relevant authorities and seeking advice to ensure their rights are upheld and any violations are addressed accordingly.

These Regulations amend the National Minimum Wage Regulations 2015 (“the 2015 Regulations”) (S.I. 2015/621). These Regulations come into force on 1st April 2023.
Regulation 2(2) increases the rate of the national living wage for workers who are aged 23 or over from £9.50 to £10.42 per hour (regulation 4 of the 2015 Regulations).
Regulation 2(3)(a) increases the rate of the national minimum wage for workers who are aged 21 or over (but not yet aged 23) from £9.18 to £10.18 per hour (regulation 4A(1)(a) of the 2015 Regulations).
Regulation 2(3)(b) increases the rate of the national minimum wage for workers who are aged 18 or over (but not yet aged 21) from £6.83 to £7.49 per hour (regulation 4A(1)(b) of the 2015 Regulations).
Regulation 2(3)(c) increases the rate of the national minimum wage for workers who are under the age of 18 from £4.81 to £5.28 per hour (regulation 4A(1)(c) of the 2015 Regulations).
The apprenticeship rate applies to workers within regulation 5(1)(a) and (b) of the 2015 Regulations. Regulation 2(3)(d) of these Regulations increases the rate for such workers from £4.81 to £5.28 per hour (regulation 4A(1)(d) of the 2015 Regulations).
Regulation 2(4) increases the accommodation offset amount which is applicable where any employer provides a worker with living accommodation from £8.70 to £9.10 for each day that accommodation is provided (regulation 16(1) of the 2015 Regulations).

4
Nature of declaration
(1)
An equivalence declaration in respect of a service for a relevant year is a declaration within any of subsections (2) to (5).
(2)
A declaration is within this subsection if it is provided before the beginning of the relevant year and it is to the effect that—
(a)
in the relevant year there will be no non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service, or
(b)
in the relevant year non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service will be remunerated in respect of their UK work in relation to the service at a rate that is equal to or exceeds the national minimum wage equivalent.
(3)
A declaration is within this subsection if it is provided during the relevant year and it is to the effect that—
(a)
in what remains of the relevant year there will be no non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service, or
(b)
in what remains of the relevant year non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service will be remunerated in respect of their UK work in relation to the service at a rate that is equal to or exceeds the national minimum wage equivalent.
(4)
A declaration is within this subsection if it is provided during the relevant year and it is to the effect that—
(a)
in so much of the relevant year as has already occurred—
(i)
there have been no non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service, or
(ii)
non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service have been remunerated in respect of their UK work in relation to the service at a rate that is equal to or exceeds the national minimum wage equivalent, and
(b)
in what remains of the relevant year—
(i)
there will be no non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service, or
(ii)
non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service will be remunerated in respect of their UK work in relation to the service at a rate that is equal to or exceeds the national minimum wage equivalent.
(5)
A declaration is within this subsection if it is provided after the end of the relevant year and it is to the effect that—
(a)
in the relevant year there were no non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service, or
(b)
in the relevant year non-qualifying seafarers working on ships providing the service were remunerated in respect of their UK work in relation to the service at a rate that is equal to or exceeds the national minimum wage equivalent.
(6)
For the purposes of this Act, the national minimum wage equivalent is an hourly rate specified in regulations.
(7)
Regulations may make provision for determining for the purposes of this Act—
(a)
the hourly rate at which a non-qualifying seafarer is remunerated in any period in respect of any work, and
(b)
whether, or the extent to which, a non-qualifying seafarer’s work in relation to a service to which this Act applies is UK work.
(8)
Regulations under subsection (7)(a) may in particular make—
(a)
any provision referred to in section 2(2) to (6) of the National Minimum Wage Act 1998;
(b)
provision relating to currency conversion.
(9)
The Secretary of State must in making regulations under this section seek to secure that a non-qualifying seafarer is for the purposes of this section remunerated at a rate equal to the national minimum wage equivalent only if their remuneration is in all the circumstances broadly equivalent to the remuneration they would receive if they qualified for the national minimum wage.
(10)
In this Act, “UK work” means work which is carried out in the United Kingdom or its territorial waters.

Prompt: Residents in an English town are concerned that their local authority has not implemented separate food waste collections, as required by the Environment Act 2021. The deadline has passed, and there is no plan in place. What legal obligations does the local authority have under the Act, and what legal remedies are available to the residents to enforce compliance?
Actual Answer: Under the Environment Act 2021, specifically Section 57, which inserts Section 45AZB into the Environmental Protection Act 1990, local authorities in England are legally obligated to arrange for the separate collection of food waste from households; failure to do so constitutes a breach of statutory duty. Residents can raise the issue with the local authority by submitting formal complaints requesting compliance, engage with local councillors and Members of Parliament (MPs) to advocate for action, and may have standing to apply for a judicial review of the local authority's failure to comply with statutory duties, as established in cases like R (on the application of Greenpeace Ltd) v Secretary of State for Trade and Industry [1998] Env LR 415; they must act promptly and within three months of the grounds arising.
Response:
The Environment Act 2021 imposes clear obligations on local authorities in England to implement separate food waste collection systems. Here’s a breakdown of the legal obligations and available remedies for residents:

### Legal Obligations of Local Authorities:
1. **Implementation Requirement**: The Act mandates that local authorities must establish separate bins or collection schemes for residual household waste, recyclables, and organic waste (including food waste). This is typically required within a specified timeframe, often 12 months from the Act's enactment.

2. **Enforcement Powers**: Failure to comply can result in enforcement actions by the Environment Agency (EA). The EA has broad powers to investigate, issue enforcement notices, and impose fines or penalties if authorities are found non-compliant.

3. **Duty to Provide Information**: Local authorities must make reasonable efforts to inform residents about the new collection schemes, including how, where, and when to separate food waste.

4. **Inspections and Audits**: The EA can inspect local authorities to verify compliance with the Act, ensuring that food waste is being collected separately and appropriately as organic waste.

### Legal Remedies Available to Residents:
1. **Complaint to the Local Authority**:
   - Residents can formally complain to their local council about the lack of implementation. This should be done in writing, stating specific concerns about non-compliance with the Environment Act.
   - Councils are required to respond and take action, or else face potential enforcement from the EA.

2. **Escalation to the Environment Agency (EA)**:
   - If the local authority does not address the complaint, residents can report the issue to the EA. The EA will investigate and may issue an enforcement notice requiring compliance within a specified timeframe.
   - Residents can also request regular updates on the investigation and its outcome.

3. **Court-Driven Remedies**:
   - **Injunctions**: If the council fails to implement the required system, residents can seek an injunction in the courts to compel compliance. This is a powerful tool as it can force the local authority to act.
   - **Compensation**: In some cases, residents may be able to claim compensation for damages caused by improper waste management practices.

4. **Public Campaigns and Advocacy**:
   - Residents can organize campaigns or join existing movements advocating for better waste management practices. This can pressure local authorities into complying with the Act.
   - Social media and local forums can be effective platforms to raise awareness and gather support.

5. **Freedom of Information Requests (FOI)**:
   - Residents may use FOI requests to obtain documents related to the council's decision-making process on waste management. This could reveal internal communications or policies that indicate a failure to comply with the Environment Act.

6. **Judicial Review**:
   - If residents believe the local authority’s actions (or inactions) are unlawfully inconsistent with the Environment Act, they can apply for a judicial review. This involves challenging the decision-making process of the council through the courts.

### Time Sensitivity:
It's crucial that residents act promptly. Legal challenges may have time limits depending on when the non-compliance was identified. Delays in seeking remedies could limit the chances of success.

### Conclusion:
While local authorities bear the primary responsibility, residents can take proactive steps to enforce their rights and ensure compliance with the Environment Act. Collective action, supported by legal recourse, is an effective way to address this issue.

These Regulations bring into force provisions of the Environment Act 2021 (c. 30) (“the Act”). These are the sixth commencement regulations made by the Secretary of State under the Act.
Regulation 2 brings into force on 1st April 2023 specified sections of the Act.
Section 68 amends Part 4 of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 (c. 43) (“the 1990 Act”) in relation to enforcement against litter, and other offences of littering from a vehicle and the unauthorised distribution of free printed material, insofar as it relates to England.
Section 69(2) and (4) amend sections 33ZA and 34ZA of the 1990 Act to allow the minimum, maximum and default levels of fixed penalty notices under those sections, and the time period under which a lesser amount may be treated as payment of the fixed penalty, to be varied.
Regulation 3 brings into force on 1st November 2023 section 19 of the Act (policy statement on environmental principles: effect) insofar as it is not already in force. Section 19 sets out the legal duty on Ministers of the Crown in using the environmental principles policy statement. It also details the relevant exemptions to the duty to have due regard to the policy statement.

Prompt: An employee lives in Wales but works in England. They are planning to take Shared Parental Leave (SPL) following the birth of their child. They are unsure how the differences between Welsh and English regulations might affect their entitlement and whether their residence in Wales impacts their rights. Under the Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014, what are their rights, and does their place of residence affect their entitlement?
Actual Answer: Under the Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014, which are authorized by the Employment Rights Act 1996, an employee's entitlement to Shared Parental Leave (SPL) is determined by their employment status and specific eligibility criteria, irrespective of their place of residence. The regulations apply uniformly across England and Wales. To qualify for SPL, the employee must have been continuously employed by the same employer for at least 26 weeks by the end of the 15th week before the expected week of childbirth and remain employed at the start of each period of SPL taken. Additionally, their partner must have worked (employed or self-employed) for at least 26 of the 66 weeks before the expected week of childbirth and have earned an average of at least £30 per week in 13 of those weeks. These criteria are outlined in the Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014, specifically in Part 2, Chapter 1, Regulation 6. Therefore, an employee residing in Wales and working in England is entitled to SPL, provided they meet these eligibility requirements, with their place of residence having no impact on their entitlement.
Response:
The employee in question resides in Wales but works in England and plans to take Shared Parental Leave (SPL) following their child's birth. Here is a structured analysis of their potential entitlements and considerations:

1. **Eligibility Under 2014 Regulations**:
   - The Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014 apply generally, requiring 26 weeks of continuous employment with the same employer before the birth, along with meeting other criteria such as age and parental status.

2. **Cross-Border Considerations**:
   - The employee's residence in Wales may influence their eligibility under Welsh regulations. It is possible that certain benefits or protections available in Wales do not apply when working in England, potentially affecting SPL entitlements.

3. **Employer Policies and Compliance**:
   - Employers in England might have policies based on English regulations, which could conflict with Welsh laws. The employer's approach to cross-border employment and compliance with both sets of regulations is crucial.

4. **Parental Responsibility and Entitlements**:
   - Understanding the specific definition of parental responsibility in Wales compared to England may impact how leave is allocated and utilized by the employee.

5. **Administrative Aspects**:
   - Differences might exist in how leave periods are structured, notice requirements, and payment mechanisms between Welsh and English regulations, affecting both the employer's obligations and the employee's experience.

6. **Dispute Resolution**:
   - The role of ACAS in mediating disputes involving both sets of regulations is important. Employees may need to navigate these complexities if they encounter issues with their employer's application of regulations.

7. **Recent Regulatory Updates**:
   - Any amendments or updates to the 2014 regulations could impact how they are applied, especially in a cross-border context.

In conclusion, while the employee resides in Wales, working in England introduces complex interactions between Welsh and English SPL regulations. They should consider consulting with their employer regarding compliance and potential differences in entitlements, as well as seeking advice from ACAS if necessary, to ensure their rights are protected under both sets of laws.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations amend the Maternity and Parental Leave etc. Regulations 1999 (S.I. 1999/3312), the Paternity and Adoption Leave Regulations 2002 (S.I. 2002/2788) and the Shared Parental Leave Regulations 2014 (S.I. 2014/3050). They also amend the Paternity and Adoption Leave (Adoption from Overseas) Regulations 2003 (S.I. 2003/921) and the Shared Parental Leave and Paternity and Adoption Leave (Adoptions from Overseas) Regulations 2014 (S.I. 2014/3092) to ensure equivalent provision for those adopting children from overseas.
The amendments extend existing requirements that apply to employers when redundancy situations arise where an employee is on maternity, adoption or shared parental leave, so that those requirements can also apply during pregnancy and for a period of time after that leave has ended. For those taking shared parental leave who have not taken maternity or adoption leave, there is a six-week threshold of continuous leave that needs to be met for the requirements to apply for a period of time after shared parental leave has ended. Where the six-week threshold is not met, the requirements apply during shared parental leave.
A full impact assessment has not been produced for this instrument as no, or no significant, impact on the private, voluntary or public sector is foreseen. A full impact assessment has been prepared in relation to the Protection from Redundancy (Pregnancy and Family Leave) Act 2023 and to which this instrument gives effect, and a copy is available at https://bills.parliament.uk/bills/3191/publications.

Prompt: A tenant in Wales is experiencing severe damp and mold in their rented property, which the landlord has failed to address despite repeated requests. Under the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016, what are the landlord's obligations regarding repairs and safety, and what actions can the tenant take to enforce these obligations?
Actual Answer: Under the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016, landlords are obligated to maintain rental properties in a condition fit for human habitation. Specifically, Section 91 mandates that landlords must ensure the dwelling is fit for human habitation both at the start and throughout the duration of the tenancy. Section 92 requires landlords to keep in repair the structure and exterior of the dwelling, including drains, gutters, and external pipes, and to maintain installations for the supply of water, gas, electricity, sanitation, space heating, and heating water. If a landlord fails to address severe damp and mold despite repeated requests, the tenant should notify the landlord in writing, keeping records of all communications. If the landlord remains unresponsive, the tenant can contact the local authority's Environmental Health department, which can inspect the property and issue improvement notices. Additionally, the tenant may apply to the court for an order requiring the landlord to carry out repairs. It's advisable to seek legal advice before considering actions like withholding rent or arranging for repairs independently, as these carry legal risks.
Response:
Under the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016, landlords in Wales have a clear legal obligation to ensure that rented properties are fit for human habitation. Specifically, the Renting Homes (Fitness for Human Habitation) (Wales) Regulations 2022 outline the standards that must be met, including addressing issues like severe damp and mold.

**Landlord's Responsibilities:**
1. **Duty to Ensure Fitness:** The landlord must take reasonable steps to identify and rectify hazards such as damp and mold, ensuring the property is safe and habitable.
2. **Legal Requirement:** As per Section 91(1) of the Renting Homes Act, maintaining a safe and habitable living environment is fundamental.

**Tenant's Actions:**
1. **Document the Issue:** Inform the landlord in writing, providing clear evidence of the problem.
2. **Report to Authorities:** If unresolved, report the issue to the Renting Homes Housing Quality Regulator or local housing authority, which may inspect the property and enforce action against the landlord.
3. **Consider Legal Recourse:** If necessary, tenants can pursue legal action to enforce their rights.

**Additional Considerations:**
- Tenant safety is paramount, and they should not be forced to endure unsafe living conditions.
- There may be specific time limits or standards for addressing repairs, which tenants should be aware of.

In summary, both landlords and tenants have defined responsibilities and rights under the law. Tenants can take proactive steps to enforce their legal rights when necessary.

14.—(1) The contract-holder must notify the landlord as soon as reasonably practicable of any fault, defect, damage or disrepair which the contract-holder reasonably believes is the landlord’s responsibility.
(2) Where the contract-holder reasonably believes that any fault, defect, damage or disrepair to the fixtures and fittings or items listed in any inventory is not the landlord’s responsibility, the contract-holder must, within a reasonable period of time, carry out repairs to such fixtures and fittings or other items listed in any inventory, or replace them.
(3) The circumstances in which paragraph (2) applies include where the fault, defect, damage or disrepair has occurred wholly or mainly because of an act or omission amounting to a lack of care(1) by the contract-holder, any permitted occupier or any person visiting the dwelling.

Emergencies: landlord’s right to enter the dwelling
16.—(1) In the event of an emergency which results in the landlord needing to enter the dwelling without notice, the contract-holder must give the landlord immediate access to the dwelling.
(2) If the contract-holder does not provide access immediately, the landlord may enter the dwelling without the permission of the contract-holder.
(3) If the landlord enters the dwelling in accordance with paragraph (2), the landlord must use all reasonable endeavours to notify the contract-holder that they have entered the dwelling, as soon as reasonably practicable after entry.
(4) For the purpose of paragraph (1), an emergency includes—
(a)
something which requires urgent work to prevent the dwelling or dwellings in the vicinity from being severely damaged, further damaged or destroyed, and
(b)
something which, if not dealt with by the landlord immediately, would put at imminent risk the health and safety of the contract-holder, any permitted occupier of the dwelling or other persons in the vicinity of the dwelling.
Commencement Information

Reg. 16 in force at 1.12.2022, see reg. 1 (as amended by The Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016 (Commencement No. 2 and Consequential Amendments) Order 2022 (S.I. 2022/906), art. 5)

Prompt: A retailer in Wales is found selling alcohol below the minimum unit price set by the Public Health (Minimum Price for Alcohol) (Wales) Act 2018. They argue that discounts and promotions allow them to reduce prices. What does the Act stipulate regarding minimum alcohol pricing, and what penalties could the retailer face for non-compliance?
Actual Answer: Under the Public Health (Minimum Price for Alcohol) (Wales) Act 2018, it is an offence for alcohol retailers in Wales to sell alcohol below the applicable minimum price, regardless of discounts or promotions. The Act defines the minimum price using the formula M × S × V, where M is the minimum unit price (set at 50p), S is the percentage strength of the alcohol, and V is the volume in litres. Non-compliance can result in enforcement actions by local authorities, including the issuance of fixed penalty notices of £200 for each offence. Therefore, retailers must adhere to the minimum pricing regulations, as discounts and promotions do not permit selling alcohol below the established minimum price.
Response:
The Public Health (Minimum Price for Alcohol) (Wales) Act 2018 establishes a minimum unit pricing system for alcohol in Wales. Here's a structured summary of the key points:

1. **Minimum Unit Pricing**: The Act sets a minimum price per unit of alcohol, typically based on factors like 35 units per 100ml for beer, wine, and spirits. This targets cheaper, stronger drinks to reduce their affordability.

2. **Exceptions and Promotions**: While promotions or discounts may be permitted if they don't consistently bring prices below the minimum, frequent or systematic use to sell below the threshold constitutes non-compliance.

3. **Penalties for Non-Compliance**:
   - **Initial Violation**: A fine of several hundred pounds upon the first offense.
   - **Subsequent Offenses**: Fines increase, potentially leading to license revocation, preventing legal business operations.

4. **Enforcement Mechanisms**: Local authorities or trading standards officers enforce the law by inspecting pricing and sales methods to ensure compliance.

In your case, if the retailer consistently sells alcohol below the minimum using discounts, they are likely violating the Act. Penalties would start with a fine and escalate upon further non-compliance.

Prompt: A homeowner in Wales wants to build a large extension to their property without applying for planning permission, arguing that it's within permitted development rights. Under the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Wales) Order 1995 and recent amendments, what are the rules regarding extensions, and when is planning permission required?
Actual Answer:
Under the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Wales) Order 1995, as amended, specific conditions allow certain extensions to be built without a formal planning application, known as permitted development rights. Below are the key provisions relevant to the homeowner’s question:
Relevant Provisions for Extensions:
Volume Limitations:
                        * Terraced Houses or Properties on Article 1(5) Land: The cumulative volume of the extension must not exceed the volume of the original dwellinghouse by more than 50 cubic meters or 10% (whichever is greater).
                        * Other Houses: The cumulative volume must not exceed 70 cubic meters or 15% (whichever is greater).
                        * Absolute Limit: In all cases, the increase must not exceed 115 cubic meters.
Height Restrictions:
                        * The height of the extension must not exceed the highest part of the existing roof.
                        * For properties with a flat roof, the extension must not be taller than the height of the original dwellinghouse.
Proximity to Boundaries:
                        * No part of the extension should be nearer to any highway than the nearest part of the original dwellinghouse unless the extension is at least 20 meters from the highway.
Designated Areas:
                        * Properties in designated areas such as conservation areas, National Parks, or Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty have more restricted permitted development rights, potentially requiring formal planning permission even for smaller extensions.
Important Considerations:
                        * Amendments: The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Amendment) (Wales) Orders 2014 and 2019 introduce specific changes and clarifications but do not fundamentally alter the provisions related to standard extensions under Schedule 2, Part 1. The 2014 amendment refines some criteria for residential projects, while the 2019 amendment includes updates relevant to designated areas and certain types of land use.
                        * Verification with Authorities: Due to potential nuances or recent legislative changes that could affect individual cases, consulting the local planning authority or a professional planner is crucial to confirm compliance with current regulations.
Response:
In Wales, the rules regarding extensions are governed by the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Wales) Order 1995, which outlines what developments can be done without planning permission. Here's a structured summary of the key points:

1. **Permitted Development Limits**: 
   - Single-storey extensions, such as garage conversions or small additions, are generally permitted if they don't exceed specific size thresholds, typically measured by floor area.

2. **Thresholds for Planning Permission**:
   - Extensions that are deemed "large" may require planning permission. The 1995 Order specifies that if the extension exceeds certain measurements (e.g., square meters), it is no longer considered minor and thus requires full planning approval.

3. **Recent Amendments and Updates**:
   - It's important to consult recent legislation as updates have been made over time, which may have altered the specific thresholds or requirements for extensions.

4. **Impact on Neighborhood**:
   - Even if the extension doesn't meet size criteria, it must not be visually prominent nor significantly alter the property's appearance or impact neighboring interests, potentially necessitating planning permission.

5. **Protected Areas**:
   - Properties in conservation areas, World Heritage Sites, or other protected locations may have additional restrictions, requiring special approvals for any development.

6. **Building Standards**:
   - Compliance with safety regulations and building standards is essential. Local authorities might require inspections or approvals to ensure structural integrity and safety.

In conclusion, a large extension likely exceeds the permitted limits under the 1995 Order unless it's classified as minor development. Therefore, planning permission is generally required for larger projects. Homeowners should consult their local planning office to determine whether their proposed extension meets the criteria or if planning permission is necessary.

This Order amends the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 1995 (“the GPDO”).
Article 3 of, and Schedule 2 to, the GPDO confer permitted development rights in respect of certain development. Where such rights are conferred, an application for planning permission is not required.
Article 2 of this Order amends Schedule 2 to the GPDO by inserting a new Part 3A (Temporary Buildings and Changes of Use for Public Health Emergency Purposes) to permit certain development in Wales for the purposes of preventing, controlling or mitigating the effects of, or taking other action in connection with a public health emergency in the United Kingdom.
The development permitted is the change of use of a building or land to Class C2 (Residential institutions) or Class D1 (Non-residential institutions) of the Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987, and the provision of buildings or other structures.
The permitted development is subject to conditions and limitations which are also set out in the new Part 3A.

Prompt: A parent in Wales is seeking additional learning support for their child, who has been diagnosed with special educational needs (SEN). How does the Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 protect the child’s right to education, and what steps should the parent take to ensure their child receives the necessary support?
Actual Answer:
The Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 provides a strong legal framework to protect the rights of children with special educational needs (SEN) in Wales, ensuring they receive appropriate education and support. Here's how the Act safeguards these rights and the steps parents should take:
How the Act Protects the Child’s Right to Education
                           * Definition of Additional Learning Needs (ALN) (Section 2): The Act defines ALN as a learning difficulty or disability that requires additional learning provision. This ensures children who face significantly greater learning challenges than their peers or have disabilities affecting their use of educational facilities are identified and supported.
                           * Individual Development Plans (IDPs) (Section 10): The Act mandates the creation of IDPs for children with ALN. These comprehensive, tailored plans detail the specific support required and are maintained by local authorities or educational institutions, guaranteeing that each child's unique needs are met.
                           * Duties of Local Authorities and Schools (Sections 11 and 14): Local authorities and the governing bodies of maintained schools have a duty to identify children with ALN and make appropriate provisions. They must review these provisions regularly to ensure their effectiveness and adapt them as needed.
                           * Participation and Rights (Section 6): The Act emphasizes involving children and their parents in the decision-making process regarding ALN support. Authorities must also consider the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, reinforcing a rights-based approach.
                           * Access to Information and Advice (Section 9): The Act requires local authorities to provide parents with information and advice on ALN and the available support, empowering them to make informed decisions.
                           * Dispute Resolution and Appeals (Sections 68 and 70): The Act establishes clear mechanisms for resolving disagreements. If parents are unsatisfied with the IDP or support provided, they can use local dispute resolution services. Additionally, they have the right to appeal decisions to the Education Tribunal for Wales.
Steps Parents Should Take to Ensure Their Child Receives Support
                           * Request an Assessment: Parents can request that the local authority assess their child for ALN. Although the Act does not explicitly state this in Section 11, it mandates that authorities and schools must decide if a child has ALN when concerns are raised.
                           * Engage in the IDP Process: Actively participate in the development and review of the IDP. Ensure the IDP reflects the child's current needs and advocate for revisions as needed.

                           * Regularly Review the IDP: Ensure that the IDP is reviewed regularly, as mandated by the Act, to keep it aligned with the child’s evolving educational needs.
This framework ensures that children with SEN in Wales receive the educational support they require, and parents are empowered to advocate effectively for their child’s rights.

The Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 provides a comprehensive framework for supporting children with special educational needs (SEN) in Wales. Here's how it protects your child's right to education and the steps you should take:

### Protection Under the Act:
1. **Identification and Assessment**: The act mandates that local authorities conduct assessments to identify if a child has SEN, ensuring they receive appropriate support.
2. **Individual Development Plan (IDP)**: Upon assessment, an IDP is created, outlining specific needs and support requirements for your child. You can request this plan from the local authority.
3. **Support Provisions**: The act requires local authorities to provide necessary support based on the IDP, ensuring your child has access to appropriate educational resources and adjustments.
4. **Non-Discrimination**: It safeguards against discrimination, requiring schools to make reasonable adjustments to accommodate children with SEN.
5. **Tribunal Dispute Resolution**: Allows for disputes to be resolved through an Education Tribunal, where parents can present evidence and seek decisions on support provision.

### Steps You Should Take:
1. **Request an Assessment**: Contact your local authority to arrange for an assessment of your child's SEN.
2. **Obtain the IDP**: Once assessed, request an IDP to outline specific support needs.
3. **Monitor Support Implementation**: Work with schools and the local authority to ensure the IDP is implemented effectively.
4. **Seek Mediation or Tribunal if Necessary**: If there's a disagreement about support provision, consider mediation. If unresolved, you can escalate it to the Education Tribunal for a formal decision.
5. **Stay Informed and Involved**: Keep communication with schools and local authorities, and maintain records of all interactions related to your child's education.

### Additional Considerations:
- **Age-Specific Provisions**: Be aware of the timeline for different act provisions, ensuring your child is within the correct age range for each provision.
- **Seek Advice**: Utilize resources from organizations like the Welsh Assembly Government or educational support groups for guidance on navigating the process.

By taking these steps, you can effectively advocate for your child's educational rights and ensure they receive the necessary support throughout their learning journey.

(This note is not part of the Order)
This Order brings into force provisions of the Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 (“the Act”).
The Act establishes a statutory framework for supporting children and young people with additional learning needs. This replaces the legislation surrounding special educational needs and the assessment of children and young people with learning difficulties, and in particular, transfers the responsibility for securing educational provision for those with additional learning needs who are over compulsory school age from the Welsh Ministers to the relevant local authority.
The provisions listed in article 2 come into force on 1 September 2025 in relation to those who are over compulsory school age on 1 September 2022.
Sections 40 to 44 of the Act (additional learning provision for detained persons) come into force on 1 September 2022 for those who are over compulsory school age on 1 September 2022 (article 3).
The provisions listed in paragraphs (a) to (o) of article 2 come into force on 1 September 2022 for persons in relation to whom an individual development plan is being prepared or kept under section 40 or 42 of the Act, or prepared or maintained under section 14 of the Act as a result of regulation 23 of the Additional Learning Needs (Wales) Regulations 2021 (article 4).

Prompt: An employee in Scotland has recently lost a child and is unsure of their entitlement to bereavement leave. Under the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, what are their rights, and what obligations does the employer have?
Actual Answer: Under the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, incorporated into the Employment Rights Act 1996 and the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992, employees in Scotland who have lost a child are entitled to specific rights, and employers have corresponding obligations. Section 80EA of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (as amended) grants eligible employees the right to take at least two weeks of parental bereavement leave. This leave must be taken within 56 days from the date of the child’s death and applies to the death of a child under 18. Section 80EE extends these rights to cases involving stillbirths after 24 weeks of pregnancy. Employers are obligated to provide this leave, ensuring that eligible employees can take time off without facing any detriment or dismissal related to their leave request. For statutory parental bereavement pay, Section 171ZZ6 of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992 (as amended) outlines the entitlement, specifying that the employee must meet certain conditions such as a continuous employment period of at least 26 weeks ending with the "relevant week" (the week immediately before the child’s death) and minimum earnings meeting the lower earnings limit. Section 171ZZ7 adds that employees must give notice to their employer about the weeks for which they seek parental bereavement pay, and employers may require this notice in writing. Regulations under this section may also stipulate further requirements, such as providing evidence of entitlement or conditions for determining continuous employment. In addition to these primary sections, reviewing supporting regulations linked to the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018 and related guidance is essential for comprehensive compliance. Regulations detail how leave is to be taken, how statutory pay is processed, and additional procedural requirements for both employees and employers.
Response:
**Employee Rights and Employer Obligations Under Bereavement Leave Laws in Scotland**

Under the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, employees in Scotland who lose a child are entitled to specific rights regarding bereavement leave. Here is an organized summary of these entitlements and the corresponding employer obligations:

### Entitlements for Employees:
1. **Bereavement Leave Duration:**
   - The Act provides for up to **12 weeks** of bereavement leave at 90% of the employee's usual wage, with the employer contributing a portion.
   - This period can be extended to **26 weeks** under certain conditions, such as if the child was born while the employee was on leave or if the death occurred during the pregnancy.

2. **Eligibility Criteria:**
   - The leave is available to employees who were working in Scotland at the time of the child's death.
   - It applies regardless of whether the parent or child dies first, and even if both pass away.

3. **Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay (SPBP):**
   - Employees are entitled to SPBP for a period of 12 weeks, with the employer paying a portion based on the employee's earnings.
   - The remaining portion is paid by the government through the Social Security system.

4. **Continuation of Employment protections:**
   - Under the Paternity Leave (Bereavement) Act 2024, employees may continue working without ending their leave period. This protects them from redundancy or dismissal based on economic factors during this time.

5. **Persons Abroad and Mariners:**
   - Employees who worked in EEA states or maritime roles within 26 weeks of the child's death are entitled to SPBP for those periods spent working abroad.

### Employer Responsibilities:
1. **Provide Bereavement Leave:**
   - Employers must grant the specified period of leave, ensuring it aligns with the employee's circumstances (e.g., working in Scotland or abroad).

2. **Calculate and Pay SPBP:**
   - Calculate the employer's contribution to the 12-week SPBP period.
   - Ensure accurate payment calculations, especially for employees who worked in different regions.

3. **Protect Against Redundancy:**
   - Employers must avoid redundancy actions against employees on bereavement leave, as protected by the 2024 Act.

### Process and Considerations:
- Employees should inform their employer promptly about their loss to initiate the leave process.
- If disputes arise over entitlements, they can seek advice from relevant authorities or legal professionals.

### Conclusion:
Scottish employees are granted comprehensive rights under the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act 2018, with specific protections and payments for those affected by pregnancy loss or neonatal death. Employers must adhere to these laws to support their employees during a difficult time.

Entitlement to parental bereavement leave
4.—(1) An employee is entitled to be absent from work to take parental bereavement leave if he or she—
(a)
satisfies one of the conditions specified in paragraph (2), and
(b)
complies with the notice requirements in regulation 6.
(2) The conditions referred to in paragraph (1) are that, at the date of C’s death, the employee is—
(a)
C’s parent;
(b)
C’s natural parent and named in an order made pursuant to section 51A(2)(a) of the Adoption and Children Act 2002(1) or section 11(3)(aa) of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995(2), provided that such an order has not subsequently been revoked or discharged;
(c)
a person with whom C has been placed for adoption, for so long as that placement has not been disrupted, as mentioned in paragraph (3);
(d)
an adopter—
(i)
with whom C was living, following C’s entry into Great Britain from outside the United Kingdom in connection with or for the purposes of adoption which does not involve the placement of C for adoption under the law of any part of the United Kingdom, and
(ii)
who has received official notification in respect of C;
(e)
an intended parent of C;
(f)
C’s parent in fact; or
(g)
the partner of P.
(3) For the purposes of paragraph (2)(c), a placement has been disrupted—
(a)
when C has been returned under sections 31 to 35 of the Adoption and Children Act 2002(3),
(b)
in Scotland, when C has been returned to the adoption agency, adoption society or nominated person in accordance with section 25(6) of the Adoption and Children (Scotland) Act 2007, or
(c)
when C’s placement—
(i)
with a local authority foster parent who is also a prospective adopter in accordance with section 22C of the Children Act 1989 following consideration in accordance with subsection (9B)(c) of that section, or
(ii)
with a prospective adopter in accordance with section 81 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2014,
has been terminated.
(4) Subject to paragraph (6), a person is C’s parent in fact if that person, for a continuous period of at least four weeks ending with the day on which C dies—
(a)
lived with C in the person’s own home, and
(b)
had day to day responsibility for C’s care.
(5) For the purposes of the continuous period mentioned in paragraph (4), no account is to be taken of any absences of a temporary or intermittent nature.
(6) A person is not to be regarded as C’s parent in fact if—
(a)
C is in the care of that person in premises in which any parent of C’s, or any person who is not a parent of C’s but who has responsibility for C, is living, or
(b)
that person was or is entitled to receive remuneration, whether by way of wages or otherwise, in respect of the care of C.
(7) A person has responsibility for C, for the purposes of paragraph (6)(a), if the person—
(a)
has parental responsibility, within the meaning of section 3 of the Children Act 1989, or
(b)
in Scotland, has parental responsibilities or parental rights, within the meaning of sections 1 and 2 of the Children (Scotland) Act 1995(4).
(8) For the purposes of paragraph (6)(b), the following payments are not to be regarded as remuneration—
(a)
any fee or allowance paid by a local authority to a foster parent;
(b)
payments wholly or mainly intended to reimburse the person for expenses which arise from, or are expected to arise from, the person’s care of C;
(c)
amounts received pursuant to the terms of a will, trust or similar instrument which makes provision in respect of C’s care.
(9) In this regulation—
(a)
“P” means any person who satisfies one of the conditions in paragraph (2)(a) to (f);
(b)
“partner” means a person (whether of a different sex or the same sex) who lives with C and P in an enduring family relationship but is not a relative of P of a kind specified in sub-paragraph (c);
(c)
the relatives of P referred to in sub-paragraph (b) are P’s parent, grandparent, sister, brother, aunt or uncle;
(d)
references to relationships in sub-paragraph (c)—
(i)
are to relationships of the full blood or half blood or, in the case of an adopted person, such of those relationships as would exist but for the adoption, and
(ii)
include the relationship of a child with his adoptive, or former adoptive, parents,
but do not include any other adoptive relationships.
(10) Where an employee is eligible to take parental bereavement leave under this regulation as a result of the death of more than one child, the employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave in respect of each child.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations introduce a new statutory entitlement for bereaved parents who are employees to take up to two weeks’ leave from their job called parental bereavement leave in the 56 weeks following the death of a child. These Regulations are made in exercise of the powers inserted into the Employment Rights Act 1996 (c. 18) (the “1996 Act”) by the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay Act) 2018 (c. 24).
Part 2 relates to entitlement to parental bereavement leave. The right to take parental bereavement leave is conferred by regulation 4 which sets out the conditions for entitlement which must be satisfied by the employee in order to take parental bereavement leave. These include substantive requirements, such as the employee falling within the definition of a bereaved parent (in particular, specifying the types of parental relationships in respect of which the new entitlement arises), as well as procedural requirements, such as the employee giving appropriate notices to their employer. Where an employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave under regulation 4 as the result of the death of more than one child, the employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave in respect of each child.
Regulation 5 sets out the number of weeks of parental bereavement leave that are available to a bereaved parent and gives an employee the option of taking either one or two weeks’ parental bereavement leave. The weeks taken as parental bereavement leave do not need to be taken consecutively. It also provides that parental bereavement leave may only be taken within the period of 56 weeks beginning with the date of the child’s death.
Regulation 6 details the notice requirements and other information the bereaved parent must provide to their employer before taking parental bereavement leave. An employee does not need to provide notice in writing to his or her employer, but the length of notice required to book and cancel parental bereavement leave will vary depending on whether the period the employee intends to take as parental bereavement leave falls within 56 days of the child’s death or later. Regulations 7 and 8 respectively set out when an employee’s period of bereavement leave may start and what happens when a period of parental bereavement leave is interrupted by another type of statutory leave under Part 8 of the 1996 Act.
Part 3 contains provisions applicable in relation to the taking of parental bereavement leave. Regulation 9 elaborates on the new section 80EB of the 1996 Act, by providing that an employee is entitled during his or her absence on leave to the benefit of all of his or her terms and conditions of employment apart from the right to remuneration (excluded by Section 80EB(3)(b)); also that the employee is subject to all of the obligations under those terms and conditions except in so far as they are inconsistent with the right to take parental bereavement leave (the exception appears in section 80EB(1)(b)). Regulations 10 and 11 provide for an employee’s right to return to work after taking a period of parental bereavement leave, distinguishing the case where the leave was an isolated period of absence from the case where it followed another period of statutory leave. Regulations 12 and 13 provide that an employee entitled to parental bereavement leave is protected from detriment and dismissal attributable to the fact that they took or sought to take parental bereavement leave.
Part 4 contains provisions applicable where an employee has a contractual right to parental bereavement leave, in addition to the statutory right contained within these Regulations.
These Regulations are part of a package of legislative measures and the relevant impact assessment is the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Bill impact assessment which was published on 14 May 2018. A copy of that impact assessment can be obtained from the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, Labour Market Directorate, 1 Victoria Street, London, SW1H 0ET.

Prompt: A tenant in Scotland has reported significant dampness and mold in their rented flat to the landlord, who has not taken any action. Under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006, what are the landlord's obligations, and what steps can the tenant take to enforce these obligations?
Actual Answer: Under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006, landlords are required to ensure that their rental properties meet the Repairing Standard, as defined in Section 13 of the Act. This includes ensuring that the property is wind and watertight, reasonably fit for human habitation, and that the structure and exterior are in a reasonable state of repair. Additionally, installations for the supply of water, gas, electricity, sanitation, heating, and hot water must be kept in proper working order. Significant dampness and mold indicate a failure to meet this standard. Under Section 14, landlords have a duty to ensure that the house meets the repairing standard at the start of the tenancy and throughout its duration. This duty requires landlords to complete any necessary repairs within a reasonable time after being notified by the tenant or otherwise becoming aware of the need for repairs. Failure to act within a reasonable timeframe constitutes a breach of this duty. If the landlord does not take action, the tenant can apply to the First-tier Tribunal under Section 22 of the Act. This section allows tenants to seek a decision from the Tribunal if the property does not meet the Repairing Standard. The Tribunal can investigate and issue a Repairing Standard Enforcement Order (RSEO) under Section 24, compelling the landlord to carry out the required repairs within a specified timeframe. If the landlord fails to comply with the RSEO, under Section 26, the Tribunal must notify the local authority and may consider imposing a rent relief order to reduce the tenant’s rent. The Tribunal may excuse non-compliance if the landlord demonstrates an inability to comply due to a lack of necessary rights (e.g., access) or if the required work poses a danger to any person. In such cases, the Tribunal must notify the local authority of its findings. The Housing (Scotland) Act 2006 provides tenants with clear mechanisms to address substandard housing conditions and enforce their rights against landlords who fail to fulfill their obligations. These regulations govern the procedures of the First-tier Tribunal for Scotland Housing and Property Chamber, which is responsible for handling cases brought under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006, including applications related to the Repairing Standard. The regulations ensure that disputes between tenants and landlords are resolved fairly and efficiently. They outline the rules for submitting applications, conducting hearings, issuing decisions, and enforcing orders such as Repairing Standard Enforcement Orders (RSEOs). This procedural framework directly supports tenants in seeking remedies for landlords' failures to meet their legal obligations under the Act.
Response:
**Landlord's Obligations Under the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006**

1. **Responsibility to Maintain Property in Reasonable Repair:**
   - Landlords are legally required to ensure that rented properties are in reasonable repair and free from health hazards such as dampness and mold, as per Section 3 of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006.

2. **Duty to Remediate:**
   - Upon notification by the tenant, landlords must inspect the property to assess the extent of the issue.
   - They are obligated to take prompt action to address the problem, which may involve fixing leaks, ensuring proper ventilation, or removing mold if necessary.

3. **Timeframe for Action:**
   - Landlords are expected to act within a reasonable time after being informed of the issue. This timeframe must be practical given the severity and complexity of the problem.

**Tenant's Steps to Enforce Obligations**

1. **Document Communication:**
   - The tenant should maintain detailed records of all interactions with the landlord, including dates, actions taken, and any responses from the landlord.

2. **Request Formal Inspection:**
   - If the issue is not resolved satisfactorily, tenants can request a formal inspection by the local authority, such as the Housing Services or Environmental Protection Agency.

3. **Escalation of Issues:**
   - If the landlord fails to address the problem, tenants may need to escalate the matter further. This could involve notifying the relevant authorities or pursuing legal action.

4. **Seeking Injunctions and Legal Action:**
   - Tenants have the option to apply for an injunction in court to compel the landlord to take remedial action.
   - If necessary, tenants can report the landlord's failure to act to local authorities, who may enforce against them for housing violations.

**Additional Considerations**

- **Preventing Unlawful Evictions:** Landlords are prohibited from evicting tenants due to health issues caused by poor property conditions.
- **Immunization Requirements:** While not directly related to dampness and mold, landlords must ensure compliance with immunization laws, especially if the issue impacts tenant health.

**Conclusion**

The landlord is legally bound to address dampness and mold promptly, while the tenant has rights to a healthy living environment. If the landlord fails in their obligations, tenants can take steps ranging from formal inspections to legal action to enforce their rights.

(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations amend the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006 (Modification of the Repairing Standard) Regulations 2019 by changing the date on which regulation 3(1)(b) comes into force from 1 February 2021 to 1 February 2022. Regulation 3(1)(b) of those Regulations will have the effect of repealing sections 13(f) and (g) of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2006.
Section 13 of the 2006 Act sets out the repairing standard duty for private landlords. Subsections (f) and (g) of section 13 relate to fire and carbon monoxide detection and warning equipment. Equivalent requirements are introduced by the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987 (Tolerable Standard) (Extension of Criteria) Order 2019 (S.S.I. 2019/8) which amends section 86(1) of the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987 (the tolerable standard). Subsections (f) and (g) are being repealed to remove any parallel provisions and duties.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations introduce measures to improve the energy efficiency of certain private rented property in Scotland.
The Regulations apply to domestic private rented property. They prescribe a minimum level of energy efficiency by means of the energy performance indicator included on the energy performance certificate for the property. This minimum level is set for the period from 1 October 2020 to 31 March 2022 as an energy efficiency or performance rating of E, and for the period from and after 1 April 2022 as an energy efficiency or performance rating of D. The Regulations provide that, subject to prescribed exceptions, a landlord of a domestic private rented property must not grant a new tenancy of the property after 1 October 2020, and must not continue to let the property after that date, where the energy efficiency or performance rating of the property is below the minimum level.
The Regulations make provision for the enforcement of the requirements of the Regulations by local authorities in relation to domestic private rented properties (“enforcement authority”). Landlords seeking to rely on a prescribed exemption when letting a private rented property which falls below the minimum level of energy efficiency must register that exemption on a register maintained by the local authority for their area. Where an enforcement authority considers that a landlord may be in breach of a requirement of the Regulations, it may serve a compliance notice requiring the landlord to provide evidence to the enforcement authority. Where an enforcement authority is satisfied that a landlord is in breach, it may issue a penalty notice imposing a financial penalty. The landlord may request a review of the penalty notice by the enforcement authority and, where a penalty notice is confirmed on review, may appeal against the imposition of the penalty notice to Sheriff court.

Prompt: An individual in Scotland is experiencing domestic abuse from their partner with whom they share a tenancy. They wish to remove the abuser from the home but are unsure of their rights. Under the Domestic Abuse (Protection) (Scotland) Act 2021, what legal protections are available, and what steps should they take?
Actual Answer: Individuals experiencing domestic abuse in Scotland can seek protection through several legal mechanisms. Under the Protection from Harassment Act 1997, they can apply for a Non-Harassment Order, which prohibits the abuser from engaging in threatening or harassing behavior. Additionally, the Matrimonial Homes (Family Protection) (Scotland) Act 1981 allows for an Exclusion Order to remove the abuser from the shared home and prevent them from re-entering. This Act applies not only to married couples but also to cohabitants. The individual should contact the police to report the abuse, as domestic abuse is a criminal offense under the Domestic Abuse (Scotland) Act 2018, which recognizes controlling behavior as abuse. Seeking legal advice from a solicitor experienced in domestic abuse cases is advisable to assist with applications for protective orders, and engaging with support services such as Scottish Women's Aid can provide additional assistance and guidance.
Response:
Under the Domestic Abuse (Protection) (Scotland) Act 2021, an individual in Scotland experiencing domestic abuse from a partner with whom they share a tenancy has several legal protections and steps they can take:

### Legal Protections:
1. **Domestic Abuse Protection Order**: They can apply for a non-harassment or protection order through the court. This can be done without a hearing if urgent, based on evidence of abuse.

2. **Tenant Rights**: Under tenant law, a landlord cannot evict a tenant solely due to domestic abuse unless there is a specific reason, such as significant damage or threat of imminent harm. The tenant may need a court order for eviction.

3. **Housing Benefit and Universal Credit Support**: The act provides protections related to benefits if the tenant needs to leave their home due to abuse, potentially safeguarding their housing benefits.

4. **Landlord's Role**: Landlords are expected to follow a domestic abuse disclosure protocol, which allows tenants to inform them of abuse situations, enabling the landlord to take appropriate actions, such as rehousing or support services.

### Steps to Take:
1. **Seek Legal Advice**: Consult with a legal aid service or advice center for guidance specific to their situation.

2. **Document Evidence**: Gather evidence such as photos, messages, and videos of abusive incidents to support any claims or applications made.

3. **Apply for Protection Order**: They can apply for an ex parte order if there is urgency, providing evidence to the court for swift action.

4. **Involvement of Landlord**: Engage the landlord through the disclosure protocol, potentially leading to rehousing assistance or mediation.

5. **Contact Support Services**: Reach out to domestic abuse shelters, housing charities, or local councils for emergency accommodation and advice.

6. **Consider Emergency Housing**: Access public housing specifically designated for survivors of domestic abuse if available.

7. **Legal Aid Assistance**: Seek legal aid to cover costs related to applying for protection orders or seeking support services.

By taking these steps, the tenant can address their situation effectively while protecting their rights and safety.

4
Making of domestic abuse protection notice
(1)
A senior constable may make a domestic abuse protection notice in relation to person A if the constable has reasonable grounds for believing that—
(a)
person A has engaged in behaviour which is abusive of person B,
(b)
it is necessary for a domestic abuse protection order to be made for the purpose of protecting person B from abusive behaviour by person A, and
(c)
there is a risk of person A engaging in further behaviour which is abusive of person B immediately and it is necessary to make the notice for the purpose of protecting person B from that behaviour.
(2)
In subsection (1)(c), “immediately” means in the period before the sheriff can make an interim domestic abuse protection order or a domestic abuse protection order.
(3)
It does not matter whether the abusive behaviour referred to in subsection (1)(a) took place in Scotland or elsewhere.
(4)
Before making a domestic abuse protection notice in relation to person A, the senior constable must—
(a)
take such steps as are reasonable in the circumstances—
(i)
to establish whether person A has any views in relation to the notice which person A wishes to be taken into account, and if so, to obtain those views,
(ii)
to establish whether person B has any views in relation to the notice which person B wishes to be taken into account, and if so, to obtain those views, and
(b)
take into account—
(i)
any views of which the senior constable becomes aware as a result of paragraph (a), and
(ii)
the welfare of any child whose interests the senior constable considers to be relevant to the making of the notice.
(5)
A domestic abuse protection notice may be made without the consent of person B.

(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations bring into force, on 29 June 2021, section 74(2) and part 2 of schedule 3 of the Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (“the Act”). These provisions extend extraterritorial jurisdiction to certain sexual offences under the Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2009 (asp 9), the offence of stalking under section 39 of the Criminal Justice and Licensing (Scotland) Act 2010 (asp 13) and the common law offence of assault. The provisions also make amendments to existing extraterritorial offences under section 11(1) and (2) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (c. 46).
The Bill for the Act received Royal Assent on 29 April 2021. Of those provisions extending to Scotland, section 81 and sections 85 to 91 came into force on the day the Act was passed.
