EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations make provision in connection with the redress scheme established by the Redress for Survivors (Historical Child Abuse in Care) (Scotland) Act 2021 (asp 15) (“the Act”).
Section 18 of the Act enables a person to apply for a redress payment if the person or, in the case of an application for a next of kin payment, the person in respect of whom the application is made was abused while a child, and resident in a relevant care setting in Scotland. The abuse (as defined in section 19 of the Act to include sexual abuse, physical abuse, emotional abuse and abuse which takes the form of neglect) must have occurred before 1 December 2004. The definition of “relevant care setting” in section 20 of the Act comprises residential institutions such as children’s homes and residential care facilities, as well as other residential placements in consequence of boarding out or fostering arrangements. Section 18 is subject to section 23 of the Act.
Section 23(1) of the Act enables the Scottish Ministers to make regulations providing that an application may not be made under section 18 if the person who carried out the abuse was of a specified description, if the abuse was carried out in circumstances of a specified description, if the person who was abused came to be resident in the relevant care setting concerned in specified circumstances, or if the person who was abused was resident in the relevant care setting concerned for a specified purpose.
These Regulations make provision under section 23 of the Act for the purpose of creating exceptions to eligibility to apply for a redress payment under section 18 of the Act.
Regulation 2 makes provision for an exception where a person was placed in a relevant care setting for the purpose of being provided with short-term respite or holiday under arrangements made between a parent or guardian of that person and another person.
Impact assessments have been prepared in relation to the Act and instruments under it and will be published online at www.gov.scot.

Prompt: A retailer in Scotland is considering selling alcohol below the minimum unit price due to competitive pressures. They want to know the legal implications. Under the Alcohol (Minimum Pricing) (Scotland) Act 2012, what are the retailer's obligations, and what penalties could they face for non-compliance?
Actual Answer: Under the Alcohol (Minimum Pricing) (Scotland) Act 2012, which amends the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005, retailers in Scotland are required to sell alcohol at or above a minimum unit price (MPU) set by the Scottish Ministers. This rule applies to all licensed premises, including shops, bars, restaurants, and temporary events with occasional licenses. The minimum price condition is detailed in Schedule 3, Paragraph 6A for premises licenses and Schedule 4, Paragraph 5A for occasional licenses. Alcohol must be sold at a minimum price calculated by multiplying the MPU by the strength and volume of the alcohol. As amended by The Alcohol (Minimum Price per Unit) (Scotland) Order 2018, the current MPU is set at 65 pence per unit. Retailers must comply with this minimum price, and selling alcohol below this threshold constitutes a breach of licensing conditions. If a retailer fails to meet the minimum pricing requirement, Section 36 of the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 allows the licensing board to review the premises license and impose penalties as needed. Following a review, the board may suspend the license temporarily, revoke the license entirely, or modify the license conditions to enforce compliance. These penalties aim to uphold public health and ensure responsible alcohol sales.
Response:
**Answer:**

Under the Alcohol (Minimum Pricing) (Scotland) Act 2012, Scottish retailers have specific obligations related to selling alcohol at or above the minimum unit price (MUP). The MUP is a legally mandated price per unit of pure alcohol, and it is illegal to sell alcohol below this price.

### Retailer's Obligations:
1. **Compliance Requirement**: Retailers must ensure that all sales of alcohol are made at a price equal to or above the MUP.
2. **Duty to Prevent Illegal Sales**: Retailers have a duty to prevent the sale of alcohol below the MUP. This includes taking steps to stop any third parties, such as other retailers or individuals, from selling alcohol below the MUP on your premises or through your business practices.

### Penalties for Non-Compliance:
1. **Civil Penalties**: Retailers face potential civil penalties for each illegal sale of alcohol below the MUP. These penalties can vary depending on factors like the amount and duration of non-compliance.
2. **Revocation/Suspension of License**: The Scottish Government can revoke or suspend a retail liquor license if there is consistent evidence of non-compliance with the MUP requirements. This would prevent the retailer from selling alcohol in Scotland.
3. **Criminal Proceedings**: In severe cases, failing to comply with the MUP could lead to criminal charges. This could result in fines, imprisonment, or both.

### Legal Advice:
Given the potential legal and financial consequences of non-compliance, it is strongly advised that the retailer consult a legal professional familiar with Scottish alcohol licensing laws to ensure full compliance with the Minimum Pricing Act and avoid unintended legal repercussions.

If you are unsure about your obligations under the law, seeking legal advice is essential.

(This note is not part of the Order)
This Order is made under section 2(2) of the Alcohol (Minimum Pricing) (Scotland) Act 2012 (“the 2012 Act”). It comes into force on 30 April 2024.
Section 1 of the 2012 Act inserted provisions into schedules 3 and 4 of the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005, introducing a further mandatory condition of premises licences and occasional licences. The condition is that alcohol must not be sold on the premises at a price below its minimum price. These provisions are the “minimum pricing provisions”.
Section 2(1) of the 2012 Act provides that the minimum pricing provisions expire 6 years after section 1 of the 2012 Act came fully into force unless an Order is made under section 2(2) of that Act to continue the effect of those provisions. Section 1 of the 2012 Act came fully into force on 1 May 2018. This Order continues the effect of the minimum pricing provisions.
A full Business and Regulatory Impact Assessment has been prepared by the Scottish Government and is published on the Scottish Government website. Copies may be obtained from the Scottish Government Directorate for Population Health, St Andrew’s House, Edinburgh EH1 3DG.

Prompt: A parent in Scotland believes their child requires additional support in school due to a learning difficulty. Under the Education (Additional Support for Learning) (Scotland) Act 2004 (as amended), what rights does the child have, and what steps can the parent take to secure the necessary support?
Actual Answer: Under the Education (Additional Support for Learning) (Scotland) Act 2004, as amended, children in Scotland who require additional support due to learning difficulties are legally entitled to specific rights. Education authorities have a duty to assess and provide for these needs when required. According to Section 8(1), if a parent requests an assessment to determine whether their child has additional support needs or requires a Co-ordinated Support Plan (CSP), the education authority must comply with this request unless it is deemed unreasonable. Following assessment, Section 4(1)(a) requires the education authority to make adequate and efficient provision for the identified needs, which can include specialized resources or tailored teaching approaches. If a child’s support needs involve multiple agencies, such as social work or healthcare in addition to education, Section 9(1) ensures they are entitled to a CSP, a document outlining coordinated support across agencies. Parents also have the right, under Section 12(2), to be actively involved in developing and reviewing support plans to ensure that their child’s educational requirements are fully understood and addressed. If disagreements arise regarding the support provided or decisions made, Section 18(1) grants parents the right to appeal to the Additional Support Needs Tribunal for Scotland, which can make binding rulings on disputes related to additional support. These legislative provisions provide a strong framework for ensuring children’s educational needs are met and give parents a clear process to advocate for the support their child requires.
Response:
The Education (Additional Support for Learning) (Scotland) Act 2004 (as amended) provides a comprehensive framework for addressing children's additional support needs in Scotland. Here is an organized summary of the key rights and steps a parent can take:

### Key Rights Under the Education (ASL) Act:
1. **Assessment and Identification**: Every child has the right to have their additional support needs assessed by the local authority. Parents can request this assessment without prior approval.

2. **Entitlement to Support Services**: Upon assessment, the local authority must provide or arrange necessary services. This may include in-class support, specialized resources, or one-to-one assistance from teachers or teaching assistants.

3. **Reasonable Adjustments**: Schools are required to make reasonable adjustments to accommodate a child's learning difficulty. This includes extra time during exams and access to special facilities, ensuring the child isn't unfairly disadvantaged.

4. **Access to Specialist Services**: The local authority can provide services such as speech therapy or occupational therapy, depending on the child's needs, at the parent's request.

5. **Curriculum Adaptation**: Schools must adapt their curriculum and teaching methods to meet diverse learning needs without compromising educational standards.

6. **Non-Discrimination**: Children with additional support needs are protected from discrimination by schools and have a right to an appropriate education.

7. **Transition Planning**: The Act requires plans to ensure continuity of support when a child moves between schools or stages of education.

### Steps a Parent Can Take:
1. **Request an Assessment**: A parent can contact the local authority to have their child assessed for additional support needs.

2. **Seek Support Services**: After assessment, the parent can request specific services such as specialist assistance.

3. **Liaise with Schools**: Work with the school to ensure adjustments are implemented and curriculum adaptations are made.

4. **Appeal or Complaints**: If support isn't provided, the parent can appeal or seek advice from organizations like the Children's Rights Network for Scotland.

5. **Involve External Support**: The Scottish Government's Additional Support Needs Team can assist if needed.

6. **Monitor Progress and Adjustments**: Regularly check that the child is receiving appropriate support and adjustments as required.

By understanding these rights and taking proactive steps, parents can effectively advocate for their child's educational needs, ensuring they receive the necessary support to thrive in school.

Provision of advocacy services
11.—(1) Where a child becomes the subject of a deprivation of liberty order which has effect as if it were a compulsory supervision order as provided for in regulation 3(1), the Scottish Ministers must, as soon as reasonably practicable, inform that child of the availability of children’s advocacy services.
(2) The Scottish Ministers need not comply with the requirement in paragraph (1) if, taking account of the age and maturity of the child, the Scottish Ministers consider that it would not be appropriate to do so.
(3) The Scottish Ministers may enter into arrangements (contractual or otherwise) with any person other than a local authority, CHS or SCRA for the provision of children’s advocacy services.
(4) For the purposes of this regulation, “children’s advocacy services” means services of support and representation provided for the purposes of assisting a child to convey their needs and views to the manager of the residential care setting in which they have been placed.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations make provision in connection with the provision of children’s advocacy services under section 122 of the Children’s Hearings (Scotland) Act 2011 (“the Act”).
Regulation 2 provides that these Regulations apply where the Scottish Ministers have entered into arrangements for the provision of children’s advocacy services under section 122(5) of the Act.
Regulation 3 provides that child advocacy workers must comply with the National Practice Model for Advocacy within the Children’s Hearings System published by the Scottish Government on 31 March 2020 and available at https://www.gov.scot/publications/advocacy-childrens-hearings-system-national-practice-model-guidance/pages/5/.
Regulation 4 provides that persons are only qualified to act as child advocacy workers when they have successfully completed training and qualification in accordance with that Regulation.

Prompt: An individual in NothernIreland is experiencing domestic abuse and seeks protection from their abuser. Under the Domestic Abuse and Civil Proceedings Act (NothernIreland) 2021, what legal protections are available, and what steps should they take to secure those protections?
Response:
**Legal Protections and Steps for Someone Experiencing Domestic Abuse in Northern Ireland**

**1. Understanding Legal Framework:**
- **Domestic Abuse and Civil Proceedings Act (Northern Ireland) 2021:** This Act introduces new provisions aimed at protecting victims, including the establishment of an offence of domestic abuse, which criminalizes the behavior.
- **Domestic Abuse (Northern Ireland) Order 1999:** Provides for protection orders to prevent domestic violence, which can last indefinitely.

**2. Key Protections:**
- **Protection Orders:** Available through the 1999 Order, these can include both parties if necessary, offering a formal legal barrier against further abuse.
- **Non-Harassment Orders:** Issued by courts, these prevent harassment and emotional abuse, lasting up to 2 years.
- **Special Measures in Court Proceedings:** Survivors may benefit from measures like separate waiting areas or screens to protect them during court appearances.

**3. Criminal Prosecution:**
- The 2021 Act criminalizes domestic abuse, allowing the prosecution of abusers under the new offence, which can result in fines or imprisonment.

**4. Prohibition of Cross-Examination:**
- Under the 2022 Regulations, cross-examination is prohibited if there's evidence of domestic abuse, enhancing the survivor's safety in court settings.

**5. Reporting and Support:**
- **Reporting Abuse:** Immediate action should be taken by contacting the police to report abuse, as this can lead to protection orders.
- **Legal Advice:** Consulting with legal professionals, such as Citizens Advice or Legal Aid panels, is crucial for navigating court processes and securing necessary orders.
- **Information Sharing:** Schools may be notified if there are children involved, allowing for support and intervention.

**6. Steps to Take:**
- **Seek Immediate Help:** Contact police and consider seeking Non-Harassment Orders through the courts.
- **Legal Representation:** Engage a lawyer to assist in court applications and advocate for special measures.
- **Understand Rights:** Familiarize oneself with the 1999 Order and new 2021 Act to know available options.

**7. Additional Considerations:**
- **Parental Responsibilities:** Special legal steps may be necessary if the abuser holds parental rights, requiring tailored advice from legal professionals.
- **Training and Data Collection:** These measures ensure improved handling of domestic abuse cases by service providers, enhancing support structures.

By understanding these protections and taking proactive steps, survivors can enhance their safety and secure their legal rights effectively.

31
Domestic abuse protection orders otherwise than on application
(1)
A court may make a domestic abuse protection order under this section in any of the cases set out below.
Family proceedings
(2)
The High Court or the family court may make a domestic abuse protection order against a person (“P”) in any family proceedings to which both P and the person for whose protection the order would be made are parties.
Criminal proceedings
(3)
Where a person (“P”) has been convicted of an offence, the court dealing with P for that offence may (as well as sentencing P or dealing with P in any other way) make a domestic abuse protection order against P.
(4)
But subsection (3) does not apply where the Court of Appeal is dealing with a person for an offence.
(5)
A court by or before which a person is acquitted of an offence may make a domestic abuse protection order against the person.
(6)
Where the Crown Court allows a person's appeal against a conviction for an offence, the Crown Court may make a domestic abuse protection order against the person.
Civil proceedings
(7)
The county court may make a domestic abuse protection order against a person (“P”) in any relevant proceedings to which both P and the person for whose protection the order would be made are parties.
(8)
In subsection (7) “relevant proceedings” means proceedings of a description specified in regulations made by the Secretary of State.

These Rules amend the Family Procedure Rules 2010 (“the FPR”) (S.I. 2010/2955).
Rules 3 to 6 insert provisions into Part 3A of the FPR as required by section 63 of the Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (c. 17). Rule 10 amends rule 27.11 of the FPR to make provision for the attendance at private hearings by duly authorised lawyers attending for specified purposes.

Sections 65 and 66 of the Domestic Abuse Act 2021 (c. 17) introduce new Part 4A into the Matrimonial and Family Proceedings Act 1984 and new Part 7A into the Courts Act 2003, respectively. Those provisions operate in family and civil proceedings to prohibit cross-examination in person between a party and a witness in defined circumstances, including where there is evidence of domestic abuse between them. The prohibition will apply automatically where there has been a conviction, charge (applicable in family proceedings only) or caution for a specified offence, where an on-notice protective injunction is in force between the party and witness or where there is other specified evidence of domestic abuse.
These Regulations specify the types of offences, protective injunctions and forms of evidence which will trigger the automatic prohibition of cross-examination in person between the party and witness.
Regulation 2 introduces Schedule 1 to the Regulations which contains a list of the specified offences, under the law of England and Wales (table 1), Scotland (table 2) and Northern Ireland (table 3).
Regulation 3 introduces Schedule 2 to the Regulations which contains a list of the specified protective injunctions, orders and interdicts under the law of England and Wales (table 1), Scotland (table 2) and Northern Ireland (table 3).
Regulation 4(1) introduces Schedule 3 to the Regulations which contains a list of the forms of evidence of domestic abuse which are specified. Regulation 4(2) requires that the evidence show that there has been domestic abuse between the party and the witness.
A full impact assessment has not been produced for this instrument as no, or no significant, impact on the private, voluntary or public sectors is foreseen.

Prompt: An employee in NothernIreland suspects they are being paid below the National Minimum Wage. Under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 and the National Minimum Wage Regulations (NothernIreland) 2015, what are their rights, and what steps can they take to address the issue?
Actual Answer: Under the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 and the National Minimum Wage Regulations (NothernIreland) 2015, an employee in NothernIreland who suspects they are being paid below the National Minimum Wage (NMW) has specific rights and actionable steps to address the issue. The Act mandates that employees must be paid at least the NMW, as set out in Section 1(1), which establishes the legal entitlement to minimum wage for all qualifying workers. Employers are legally required to keep accurate records of wage payments under Section 9 of the Act. These records should be sufficient to demonstrate that an employee is being paid at least the NMW. Therefore, the first step for the employee is to review their pay records to confirm any potential underpayment. Should there be a discrepancy, Section 10 grants the employee the right to formally request access to these records, enabling them to verify their calculations against the NMW requirement. If the employee identifies an underpayment, they should raise this issue with their employer, as it may be an oversight. If the employer fails to resolve the issue, the employee can escalate the matter to HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), the body responsible for enforcing compliance. While Section 13 of the Act authorizes the Secretary of State to appoint officers for enforcement purposes, Section 14 provides HMRC officers with the power to issue enforcement notices if employers are found non-compliant.  While the Act provides the primary framework, the National Minimum Wage Regulations (NothernIreland) 2015 offer additional details for specific situations, such as valuing accommodation benefits or adjusting for absences, which can influence wage calculations. For most straightforward underpayment cases, the Act alone provides the necessary rights and procedures, with the Regulations supporting only in specific circumstances affecting wage calculation. In addition to these provisions, the Employment Rights (NothernIreland) Order 1996 is also relevant as it grants the employee a procedural framework for seeking redress if they are not compensated as per the NMW. Under the 1996 Order, if an employee experiences a sustained issue with underpayment, they have the right to file a claim with an Industrial Tribunal. This Order, though not specifically addressing minimum wage rates, is essential for the employee’s right to fair wages, as it permits claims for unlawful deduction of wages or breach of contract, allowing the employee to recover underpaid amounts. The 1996 Order thus complements the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 by establishing legal recourse in cases of wage disputes.
Response:
**Rights and Steps for Addressing Potential Underpayment of National Minimum Wage in Northern Ireland**

1. **Understanding Rights:**
   - The employee has the legal right to receive at least the National Minimum Wage (NMW) as set by the National Minimum Wage Act 1998 and the National Minimum Wage Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2015.
   - They are entitled to back pay if they were underpaid, subject to any applicable time limits.

2. **Steps to Take:**

   a. **Gather Evidence:**
      - Review payslips to compare the actual hourly rate with the NMW for their job sector. This documentation is crucial for any formal complaint or dispute resolution process.

   b. **Discuss with Employer:**
      - The employee should initially approach their employer to verify if their pay meets the legal requirements. If the employer agrees and corrects the issue, it may be resolved informally.

   c. **Contact the Labour Relations Agency (LRA):**
      - For formal assistance, the LRA in Northern Ireland can investigate complaints. They will review evidence and determine compliance with NMW legislation.
      - The employee should provide detailed information about their situation when contacting the LRA.

   d. **Seek Legal Advice:**
      - If unsure of their rights or how to proceed, consulting a legal professional can provide tailored advice and strengthen their case.

   e. **Report to Public Services Ombudsman (if applicable):**
      - While not all issues fall under the ombudsman's jurisdiction, reporting through this channel might be necessary for certain complaints.

3. **Whistleblower Protection:**
   - Employees have protections against unfair dismissal or retaliation if they report NMW violations. Employers must have a valid reason for any adverse actions taken.

4. **Enforcement Action by LRA:**
   - If the employer refuses to comply, the LRA can take enforcement action, potentially leading to penalties for the employer and securing back pay for the employee.

5. **Time Limits:**
   - The employee should act promptly. There are often strict time limits for making complaints, so immediate action is advised.

In summary, the employee has rights to fair wages and can take several steps including evidence gathering, discussion with the employer, contacting the LRA, seeking legal advice, and considering further actions if necessary. This structured approach ensures that potential underpayment is addressed effectively.

Prompt: An employee in NothernIreland has recently lost a child and is unsure about their entitlement to bereavement leave and pay. Under the Parental Bereavement Leave and Pay Act (NothernIreland) 2022, what are their rights, and how can they access them?
Actual Answer:
Under the Parental Bereavement Leave and Pay Act (NothernIreland) 2022, an employee in NothernIreland who has recently lost a child is entitled to bereavement leave, and if they meet certain criteria, they may also be eligible for bereavement pay. Article 112EA(1)-(3) defines a "bereaved parent" as an employee who meets specified relationship conditions with the deceased child, which may include a caregiving role before the child’s death. Employees who lose a child under 18, or experience a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy, are entitled to at least two weeks of bereavement leave under Article 112EA(5). This leave can be taken either as a single two-week block or in two separate one-week periods. According to Article 112EA(6), this leave must be taken within at least 56 days (eight weeks) from the date of the child’s death, providing flexibility within that period.
If an employee loses more than one child, Article 112EA(7) entitles them to bereavement leave for each child. Article 112EB outlines rights during and after bereavement leave, specifying that employees on leave retain most employment terms and conditions (excluding remuneration). According to Article 112EB(1)(a)-(c), employees are entitled to return to their original or an equivalent job after bereavement leave. Furthermore, Article 112EB(3) provides that if bereavement leave coincides with other types of parental leave (such as maternity or paternity leave), the right to return applies across the entire period of absence.
To access bereavement leave, Article 112ED(a) requires employees to notify their employer as soon as reasonably practicable, specifying the intended dates for leave. Employers are obligated to grant this leave and cannot delay or refuse it. If the employee is also eligible for statutory bereavement pay, they must provide notice and any required documentation as directed under Articles 112ED(a) and (c).

**Bereavement Leave and Pay Entitlements in Northern Ireland**

Under the Parental Bereavement Leave and Pay Act (Northern Ireland) 2022, an employee who loses a child is entitled to a specific period of paid leave and reduced pay. Here's a breakdown of their rights:

1. **Entitlement Period**: 
   - The employee is initially entitled to 2 calendar weeks of paid bereavement leave.
   - After the first week, the pay is reduced to 80% of the average weekly earnings.

2. **Eligibility Criteria**:
   - Employees must have been employed by their employer for at least 26 weeks out of the previous 17 months before the loss occurs.

3. **Accessing Benefits**:
   - The employee should inform their employer as soon as possible, typically through HR or company policies, to initiate the process and access the benefit.

4. **Pay Calculation**:
   - The reduced pay is calculated based on the average weekly earnings over a reference period specified by the Act, ensuring continued income support during the leave period.

5. **Employer Protections**:
   - Employees are protected from Discrimination or retaliation related to their bereavement leave, and they cannot be dismissed or treated unfairly for taking this leave.

6. **Exceptions and Conditions**:
   - While these entitlements generally apply, there may be specific circumstances (e.g., small employer size or certain loss scenarios) that could affect eligibility, though such cases are rare.

In summary, Northern Irish employees who lose a child have structured rights to bereavement leave and pay, ensuring some financial support during a difficult time. They should reach out to their employer promptly to understand the specific steps for accessing these benefits.

EXPLANATORY NOTE
(This note is not part of the Regulations)
These Regulations are made in exercise of the powers inserted into the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996 (N.I. 16) (the “1996 Order”) by the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Act (Northern Ireland) 2022 (c. 5).
The Regulations revoke and re-enact the provisions of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023 which would otherwise cease to have effect by virtue of Article 251(1A) of the Employment Rights (Northern Ireland) Order 1996.
These Regulations provide for a statutory entitlement for bereaved parents who are employees to take up to two weeks’ leave from their job called parental bereavement leave in the 56 weeks following the death of a child.
Part 2 relates to entitlement to parental bereavement leave. The right to take parental bereavement leave is conferred by regulation 4 which sets out the conditions for entitlement which must be satisfied by the employee in order to take parental bereavement leave. These include substantive requirements, such as the employee falling within the definition of a bereaved parent (in particular, specifying the types of parental relationships in respect of which the new entitlement arises), as well as procedural requirements, such as the employee giving appropriate notices to their employer. Where an employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave under regulation 4 as the result of the death of more than one child, the employee is entitled to parental bereavement leave in respect of each child.
Regulation 5 sets out the number of weeks of parental bereavement leave that are available to a bereaved parent and gives an employee the option of taking either one or two weeks’ parental bereavement leave. The weeks taken as parental bereavement leave do not need to be taken consecutively. It also provides that parental bereavement leave may only be taken within the period of 56 weeks beginning with the date of the child’s death.
Regulation 6 details the notice requirements and other information the bereaved parent must provide to their employer before taking parental bereavement leave. An employee does not need to provide notice in writing to his or her employer, but the length of notice required to book and cancel parental bereavement leave will vary depending on whether the period the employee intends to take as parental bereavement leave falls within 56 days of the child’s death or later. Regulations 7 and 8 respectively set out when an employee’s period of bereavement leave may start and what happens when a period of parental bereavement leave is interrupted by another type of statutory leave under Part 9 of the 1996 Order.
Part 3 contains provisions applicable in relation to the taking of parental bereavement leave. Regulation 9 elaborates on the new Article 112EB of the 1996 Order, by providing that an employee is entitled during his or her absence on leave to the benefit of all of his or her terms and conditions of employment apart from the right to remuneration (excluded by Article 112EB(2)(b)); also that the employee is subject to all of the obligations under those terms and conditions except in so far as they are inconsistent with the right to take parental bereavement leave (the exception appears in Article 112EB(1)(b)). Regulations 10 and 11 provide for an employee’s right to return to work after taking a period of parental bereavement leave, distinguishing the case where the leave was an isolated period of absence from the case where it followed another period of statutory leave. Regulations 12 and 13 provide that an employee entitled to parental bereavement leave is protected from detriment and dismissal attributable to the fact that they took or sought to take parental bereavement leave.
Part 4 contains provisions applicable where an employee has a contractual right to parental bereavement leave, in addition to the statutory right contained within these Regulations.
Part 5 (regulations 16 to 22) contains provisions in respect of the Transitional arrangements that will ensure a continuity of entitlement between the revoked Regulations and current Regulations. This part also contains the revocation of the Parental Bereavement Leave Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2023.
A separate impact assessment has not been prepared for these Regulations. The Regulations are part of a package of legislative measures and the relevant impact assessment is the Parental Bereavement (Leave and Pay) Bill impact assessment which was published in April 2020. ( https://www.economy-ni.gov.uk/sites/default/files/consultations/economy/equality-impact-assessment-parental-bereavement-leave-and-pay.pdf).

9.—(1) An employee who takes parental bereavement leave, is, during any period of leave—
(a)
entitled to the benefit of all of the terms and conditions of employment which would have applied if the employee had not been absent; and
(b)
bound by any obligations arising under those terms and conditions, subject only to the exception in Article 112EB(1)(b) of the 1996 Order(1).
(2) In paragraph (1)(a), “terms and conditions of employment” has the meaning given by Article 112EB(2) of the 1996 Order, and accordingly does not include terms and conditions about remuneration.
(3) For the purposes of Article 112EB of the 1996 Order, only sums payable to an employee by way of wages or salary are to be treated as remuneration.
(4) In the case of accrual of rights under an employment-related benefit scheme within the meaning given by paragraph 7 of Schedule 5 to the Social Security (Northern Ireland) Order 1989(2), nothing in paragraph (1)(a) imposes a requirement which exceeds the requirements of paragraph 5D(3) of that Schedule.

Because the tenant has lived in the property for two years, the landlord’s four-week notice does not meet this requirement and is therefore invalid. The tenant may choose to inform the landlord in writing that the notice is invalid due to the insufficient notice period, referencing Article 14(1), which states that a notice to quit is only valid if it complies with the minimum notice periods required by law. Prompt: An individual in NothernIreland is being harassed and stalked by an ex-partner, causing them significant distress. Under the Stalking Act (NothernIreland) 2022, what legal protections are available to them, and what steps should they take to ensure their safety?
Actual Answer: Under the Protection from Stalking Act (NothernIreland) 2022, individuals in NothernIreland who are being harassed and stalked by an ex-partner can rely on specific legal protections. The Act clearly defines stalking as a criminal offense in Section 1, where engaging in a course of conduct causing another person to experience fear, alarm, or substantial distress constitutes stalking. Such conduct includes following, contacting, monitoring usage of electronic communications, and other invasive behaviors. Offenders can face severe penalties, with up to 10 years imprisonment or a fine upon conviction on indictment, or up to 12 months imprisonment or a statutory maximum fine upon summary conviction. Additionally, the Act allows for Stalking Protection Orders (SPOs), detailed in Section 7, which the Chief Constable can apply for. These orders are designed to prevent further stalking activities by imposing specific prohibitions or requirements on the stalker. The eligibility for an SPO is based on evidence that the individual has engaged in stalking, poses a risk related to stalking, and that the order is necessary to protect someone from this risk. These orders can be applied against anyone residing in, or intending to visit, NothernIreland. The duration of these orders is addressed in Section 9, where an SPO can last for a minimum of two years or until further court order. The court may specify that some conditions within the SPO remain effective until further judicial review while setting others for fixed periods. This flexibility allows the protective measures to be adapted over time to match the needs of the situation. For their safety, affected individuals should report stalking incidents to the Police Service of NothernIreland (PSNI), enabling legal proceedings that could include the issuance of an SPO. Consulting legal advice and engaging with support services are also advisable steps to ensure comprehensive protection and support.
Response:
**Legal Protections and Steps for a Victim of Stalking in Northern Ireland Under the Stalking Act (NI) 2022**

**1. Understanding the Legal Framework:**
   - **Definition of Stalking:** The Stalking Act (NI) 2022 defines stalking broadly, encompassing behaviors such as following, contacting, monitoring, publishing material, interfering with property, and other actions that cause substantial distress.
   - **Substantial Distress:** The act specifies that the victim must be experiencing significant distress, which can affect their daily activities.

**2. Available Legal Protections:**
   - **Protection Orders:** Victims can apply for protection orders through the courts to prevent harassers from contacting them or coming near their place of residence.
   - **Occupation Orders:** The court may grant an occupation order requiring the harasser to leave the shared family home, granting sole occupancy to the victim.
   - **Criminal Charges:** Harassment constituting stalking can lead to criminal charges under the act, with potential penalties including fines or imprisonment.

**3. Evidence and Documentation:**
   - **Gather Evidence:** Collect all evidence such as messages, calls, photos, and witness statements attesting to the harassment.
   - **Document Distress:** Medical reports or counseling records can support claims of substantial distress.

**4. Proactive Measures:**
   - **Early Action:** Victims should not hesitate to seek help when they notice worrying behavior; proactive steps are encouraged before severity increases.

**5. Support Resources:**
   - **Support Organizations:** Contact organizations like Shelter NI for legal advice and shelter if needed.
   - **Legal Advice:** Consult with a legal advisor experienced in domestic abuse cases to navigate the court process effectively.

**6. Considerations and Exclusions:**
   - **Exceptions and Defenses:** The act includes defenses for actions taken to prevent crime or report it, which may be relevant if the abuser contests their behavior.
   - **Course of Conduct:** Repeated behavior, even non-physical, can qualify as stalking under the act.

**7. Next Steps:**
   - **Application Process:** Initiate legal proceedings to apply for protection orders and occupation orders.
   - **Seeking Civil Remedies:** Consider pursuing compensation or other civil remedies through the courts.

In summary, victims in Northern Ireland have access to protection orders, occupation orders, criminal charges, and civil remedies under the Stalking Act 2022. Prompt action, supported by evidence and legal guidance, is crucial for securing these protections and ensuring safety.

Meaning of act associated with stalking and risk associated with stalking
6.—(1) This section applies for the purposes of this section and sections 7 to 10.
(2) An “act associated with stalking” is any of the following—
(a)
following a person;
(b)
contacting, or attempting to contact, a person by any means;
(c)
publishing any statement or other material—
(i)
relating or purporting to relate to a person, or
(ii)
purporting to originate from a person;
(d)
monitoring the use by a person of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication;
(e)
entering any premises;
(f)
loitering in any place (whether public or private);
(g)
interfering with any property in the possession of a person;
(h)
giving anything to a person or leaving anything where it may be found by, given to or brought to the attention of a person;
(i)
watching or spying on a person;
(j)
acting in any other way that it would be reasonable to expect would cause a reasonable person to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress.
(3) A “risk associated with stalking” is a risk of—
(a)
a person carrying out acts associated with stalking, and
(b)
another person being a victim of those acts (if carried out).
(4) Where there is a risk associated with stalking, the person mentioned in subsection (3)(a) “poses a risk associated with stalking” to any person within subsection (3)(b).
(5) The acts mentioned in subsection (3) may be acts which the person mentioned in subsection (3)(a) knows, or ought to know, are unwelcome to a person within subsection (3)(b) even if, in other circumstances, the acts would appear harmless in themselves.
(6) A reference to being a victim of acts associated with stalking is a reference to being a target of the acts or to suffering physical or psychological harm because of, or otherwise being a victim of, the acts.

Offence of stalking
1.—(1) A person (“A”) commits an offence (in this Act referred to as the offence of stalking) where—
(a)
A engages in a course of conduct,
(b)
A’s course of conduct—
(i)
causes another person (“B”) to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress, or
(ii)
is such that a reasonable person, or a reasonable person who has any particular knowledge of B that A has, would consider to be likely to cause B to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress, and
(c)
at least one of the further conditions applies.
(2) The further conditions are—
(a)
that A engages in the course of conduct with the intention of causing B to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress;
(b)
that A knows, or ought in all the circumstances to have known, that engaging in the course of conduct would be likely to cause B to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress.
(3) If—
(a)
A is a UK national or is habitually resident in Northern Ireland, and
(b)
A’s course of conduct consists of or includes conduct occurring in a country, or territory, outside the United Kingdom,
the course of conduct is to be treated for the purposes of this section as if it occurred in Northern Ireland.
(4) In subsections (1) to (3) and this subsection—
“conduct” means—
(a)
following B or any other person,
(b)
contacting, or attempting to contact, B or any other person by any means,
(c)
publishing any statement or other material—
(i)
relating or purporting to relate to B or to any other person, or
(ii)
purporting to originate from B or from any other person,
(d)
monitoring the use by B or by any other person of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication,
(e)
entering any premises,
(f)
loitering in any place (whether public or private),
(g)
interfering with any property in the possession of B or of any other person,
(h)
giving anything to B or to any other person or leaving anything where it may be found by, given to or brought to the attention of B or any other person,
(i)
watching or spying on B or any other person, or
(j)
acting in any other way that a reasonable person, or a reasonable person who has any particular knowledge of B that A has, would expect would cause B to suffer fear, alarm or substantial distress;
“course of conduct” involves conduct on two or more occasions;
“substantial distress” means distress that has a substantial adverse effect on B’s day to day activities.
(5) It is a defence for a person charged with the offence of stalking to show that the course of conduct—
(a)
was authorised by virtue of any statutory provision or rule of law,
(b)
was engaged in for the purpose of preventing or detecting crime, or
(c)
was reasonable in the particular circumstances.
(6) A person who commits the offence of stalking is liable—
(a)
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years or a fine (or both), or
(b)
on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both).
(7) In proceedings in respect of a charge against a person of the offence of stalking, the person may be convicted of an offence under section 2 if the facts proved against the person—
(a)
do not amount to the offence of stalking, but
(b)
do amount to the offence under section 2.
(8) Subsection (7) is without prejudice to section 6(2) of the Criminal Law Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 (alternative verdicts on trial on indictment).
(9) In this section “statutory provision” has the meaning given by section 1(f) of the Interpretation Act (Northern Ireland) 1954.
Commencement Information
